bashmarks: new tricks

May 16, 2014
1 minute read

I was recently introduced to bashmarks, a great command-line script for managing “favorite” directories and quickly getting back to them.

Unfortunately, the default implementation has one limiting factor (for me, at least): its command names (e.g., l, d, etc.) are aliases that I already use.

I could have simply modified the script to use aliases that I don’t use, but where’s the friendliness in that? I wanted to craft a solution that would be configurable and usable for others.

So, I created my own fork (after deducing that the original bashmarks hasn’t been updated in some time and doesn’t seem to be merging pull requests).

TL;DR

I’m forking bashmarks in order to add some needed functionality.

The Fork

Open on Github

In my version, simply a line like this ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc:

export BASHMARKS_PREFIX="your-prefix-here"

This prefix is then used to call all the normal bashmarks functions.

For a real example, say I used this prefix:

export BASHMARKS_PREFIX="bm"

Then, my aliases would look like this:

bms <bookmark_name> - Saves the current directory as "bookmark_name"
bmg <bookmark_name> - Goes (cd) to the directory associated with "bookmark_name"
bmp <bookmark_name> - Prints the directory associated with "bookmark_name"
bmd <bookmark_name> - Deletes the bookmark
bml - Lists all available bookmarks

Easy, simple, and it gets the job done. Enjoy!
